description: From Middle English scale, from Latin scāla, usually in plural scālae (“a flight of steps, stairs, staircase, ladder”), for *skand-slā, from scandō (“I climb”); see scan, ascend, descend, etc. Doublet of scala.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A ladder; a series of steps; a means of ascending.
An ordered, usually numerical sequence used for measurement, means of assigning a magnitude.
examples: Please rate your experience on a scale from 1 to 10.
The magnitude of an earthquake is measured on the open-ended Richter scale.

entries.meaning: Size; scope.
examples: On an enormous scale was a blood-feast.
There are some who question the scale of our ambitions.

entries.meaning: The ratio of depicted distance to actual distance.
examples: This map uses a scale of 1:10.

entries.meaning: A line or bar associated with a drawing, used to indicate measurement when the image has been magnified or reduced.
(music) A series of notes spanning an octave, tritave, or pseudo-octave, used to make melodies.
A mathematical base for a numeral system; radix.
examples: the decimal scale; the binary scale

entries.meaning: Gradation; succession of ascending and descending steps and degrees; progressive series; scheme of comparative rank or order.
A standard amount of money to be received by a performer or writer, negotiated by a union.
examples: Sally wasn't the star of the show, so she was glad to be paid scale.

verbs.description: scale (third-person singular simple present scales, present participle scaling, simple past and past participle scaled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To change the size of something whilst maintaining proportion; especially to change a process in order to produce much larger amounts of the final product.
examples: We should scale that up by a factor of 10.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To climb to the top of.
examples: Hilary and Norgay were the first known to have scaled Everest.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, computing) To tolerate significant increases in throughput or other potentially limiting factors.
examples: That architecture won't scale to real-world environments.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To weigh, measure or grade according to a scale or system.

description: From Middle English scale, from Old French escale, from Frankish and/or Old High German skala, from Proto-Germanic *skalō. Cognate with Old English sċealu (“shell, husk”), whence the modern doublet shale. Further cognate with Dutch schaal, German Schale, French écale.

entries.meaning: Part of an overlapping arrangement of many small, flat and hard pieces of keratin covering the skin of an animal, particularly a fish or reptile.

verbs.description: scale (third-person singular simple present scales, present participle scaling, simple past and past participle scaled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove the scales of.
examples: Please scale that fish for dinner.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become scaly; to produce or develop scales.
examples: The dry weather is making my skin scale.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strip or clear of scale; to descale.
examples: to scale the inside of a boiler

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take off in thin layers or scales, as tartar from the teeth; to pare off, as a surface.
examples: if all the mountains and hills were scaled, and the earth made even

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To separate and come off in thin layers or laminae.
(UK, Scotland, dialect) To scatter; to spread.
(transitive) To clean, as the inside of a cannon, by the explosion of a small quantity of powder.

description: From Middle English scale, from Old Norse skál (“bowl”) from Proto-Germanic *skēlō. Compare Danish skål (“bowl, cup”), Dutch schaal, German Schale, Old High German scāla, Old English scealu (“cup”).

entries.meaning: A device to measure mass or weight.
examples: After the long, lazy winter I was afraid to get on the scale.

entries.meaning: Either of the pans, trays, or dishes of a balance or scales.
